variant.question: Which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.text:
Block fuel is the total fuel required to operate a
segment not including the final reserve.

Basic Empty Mass includes the mass of the unusable
fuel

Trip fuel is the sum of the take-off, climb, cruise and
descent fuels or “runway to runway”.

Q) EDGG/QNNCS/IV/B0/AE/000/999/**5049N00638E025** 
A) ETNN 
B) FROM: 15/11/11 09:00 
C) TO: 16/02/1021: 50 EST 
E) AD ETNN: MOBILE TACAN NOE CH79Y IN USE. PSN **504947N0063847E** and situated 859m away FROM ARP (original position).
What could be expected?

options.text: Valid slant range indications refer to the indicated position only.
Distance indications must be corrected by 859 m.
You can approach the airport if you follow radial 259.
It is possible that the transmitter will move from the given location.

Given: X = Distance A to point of equal time (PET) between A and B E = Endurance D = Distance A to B O = Ground Speed 'on' H =Ground Speed 'back' The formula for calculating the distance X to point of equal time (PET) is:

options.text: X = D x H/ O + H
X = D x O / O + H
X = D x O x H / O + H
X = E x O x H / O + H

variant.question:
Given:
X = Distance A to point of equal time (PET) between A and B
E = Endurance
D = Distance A to B
O = Ground Speed 'on'
H =Ground Speed 'back'
The formula for calculating the distance X to point of equal time (PET) is:

options.text: X = D X H / O + H
X = E X O X H / O + H
X = D X O X H / O + H
X = D X O / O + H

Which of the following statements with regard to the PET (Point of Equal Time) is correct?

options.text: Endurance is not relevant when calculating the point of equal time.
Endurance is relevant when calculating the point of equal time.
When calculating the point of equal time fuel reserves should be accounted for.
The point of equal time is a number which is entered in field 19 of the ATC flight plan.

variant.question: Which selection best describes a Point of Equal Time PET, or Critical Point, between the departure aerodrome and the destination where one destination alternate has been nominated?  The PET is a track position from which it takes the same time to fly

options.text: onward to the destination as it would to return to the departure point.
to the destination as the flight planned time to the destination alternate.
back to the departure point as the planned flight time taken to fly to it.
to the departure point in actual or flight planned conditions.

options.text: In the midway between New York and Amsterdam.

variant.question:
Given Distance from departure to destination 270 NM 

True track 030 W/V 120/35 

TAS 125 kt 

What is the distance and time of the PET from the departure point?
Why do we normally overlook the descend phase when calculating point of equal time (PET)?

options.text: Because the descend will have an equal effect, whatever destination we decide to proceed to.
Because we never know what kind of descend clearance we will get from ATC.
Because the W/V during the descend is not known in academic situations.
Because there are so many uncertain factors in the descend phase.

variant.question:
Given Distance from departure to destination 1950 NM 

GS Out 400 kt 

GS Home 300 kt 

What is the time of the PET from the departure point?
What is true regarding the Point of Equal Time (PET)?

options.text: Endurance is irrelevant for calculating the PET.
Endurance is a factor in the calculation of the PET.
Fuel reserves should be accounted for in the calculation of the PET.
The PET should be the figure entered in the ATC flight plan item 19.
